## MATHEMATICS

9709/21  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 312, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Pure Mathematics 2

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
Use logarithms to solve the equation \(14\mathrm{e}^{-2x} = 5^{x + 1}\), giving your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 74, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 479, 92]]<|/det|>
It is given that \(\sec \theta = \sqrt{17}\) where \(0 < \theta < \frac{1}{2}\pi\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 108, 401, 127]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(\tan (\theta + \frac{1}{4}\pi)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 108, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 818, 92]]<|/det|>
By sketching a suitable pair of graphs on the same diagram, show that the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[460, 100, 536, 122]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2} x} = x^{5}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 131, 361, 149]]<|/det|>
has exactly one real root.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 131, 920, 149]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 551, 148, 570]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 545, 920, 586]]<|/det|>
Use the iterative formula \(x_{n + 1} = \sqrt[5]{\mathrm{e}^{-\frac{1}{2}x_n}}\) to determine the root correct to 4 significant figures. Give the result of each iteration to 6 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 568, 920, 587]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 421, 92]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(4\mathrm{e}^{2x}\mathrm{y} + \mathrm{y}^2 = 21.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 104, 520, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the gradient of the curve at the point (0, \(-7\) ).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 732, 92]]<|/det|>
Show by calculation that the \(x\)-coordinate of \(B\) lies between 3.0 and 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 510, 176, 528]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 510, 918, 545]]<|/det|>
Use the trapezium rule with two intervals to find an approximation to the area of the shaded region. Give your answer correct to 2 decimal places.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[888, 528, 917, 545]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 643, 92]]<|/det|>
The expression \(\operatorname {f}(\theta)\) is defined by \(\operatorname {f}(\theta) = 12 \sin \theta \cos \theta + 16 \cos^2 \theta\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 106, 146, 123]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 920, 140]]<|/det|>
Express \(\operatorname {f}(\theta)\) in the form \(R\cos (2\theta -\alpha) + k\), where \(R > 0\), \(0< \alpha < \frac{1}{2}\pi\) and \(k\) is a constant. State the values of \(R\) and \(k\), and give the value of \(\alpha\) correct to 4 significant figures. [5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 595, 180, 612]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[183, 593, 715, 612]]<|/det|>
Find the smallest positive value of \(\theta\) satisfying the equation \(\operatorname {f}(\theta) = 17\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 594, 920, 612]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[428, 74, 569, 92]]<|/det|>
